About

    I'm a User Experience Designer with a background in front-end/back-end development and quality assurance.

ITV Hub

Redesigning ITV Hub Search feature

Please note these designs have been altered from the final designs and made more generic due to non-disclosure obligations.

  • Client: ITV Hub - Date: June 2021 - Service: UX Design .

Summary

ITV Hub is a service for watching live TV, catchup TV and streaming video on demand. Users can find content by browsing or they can use the search tool for finding specific content. I completely redesigned the Search tool.

Problem

A combination of user interviews, surveys and task-based usability testing and analytics data of our current search revealed the following.

  • On Browser, no messaging around unsuccessful searches (dead-end results) so the user is unsure if the problem lies at their end.
  • Search is not intelligent (doesn't handle spelling mistakes).
  • A number of users refer to certain shows by their acronyms and when searching by popular acronyms the appropriate show is not returned.
  • On Smart TV, due to the lack of fuzzy search and predictive search, a high number of TV remote keypresses were required to return some content.
  • The 'focus navigation' pattern used by Smart TV creates restrictions such as having to navigate over a row of characters on a keyboard before being able to select one of the search results.
  • Some of the matches for content were no longer available to watch so would create dead-end journeys.

Solution

Integrated a new search engine that offers fuzzy search and predictive search as well as matching on synonyms. An availability check is also performed to ensure all searchable content is currently available.

| Returned results in a grid of thumbnails enabling matches to be surfaced after a few key presses. For Smart TV created a mini keyboard variant that allowed more space to display search results while still maintaining readability. Introduced recent searches links for users that regularly search for the same show.


Tools and techniques

User interviews, analytics data, user surveys, prototypes plugged into a development version of the new search API, task-based usability tests (Userzoom) both to identify current problems and validate design solutions.


Case Study

Full case study unavailable until the final work has been released. I'm happy to elaborate if there are any specific questions that I can answer without disclosing sensitive information.


ITV Hub

Making signed and audio described content more discoverable

Please note these designs have been altered from the final designs and made more generic due to non-disclosure obligations.

  • Client: ITV Hub - Date: February 2021 - Service: UX Design .

Summary

ITV Hub is a service for watching live TV, catchup TV and streaming video on demand. Some of the programmes have Audio Described and Signed versions but this content is not easily discoverable. The solution allowed accessible content to be easily grouped together and navigated to.


Problem

If a user wanted to browse for Audio Described and Signed content they would not know if a programme had those specific versions until they went from the homepage or category page to that programme/episode page. It was apparent this was a significant pain point for those wishing to view accessible content.


Solution

By using the category page (which groups by genres such as Drama, Documentaries, Sport) and creating additional categories 'Audio Described' and 'Signed - BSL' the user will be able to browse programmes that have Audio Described and Signed versions.

AD and/or BSL icons on the episode tile of each episode as well as the main programme image would further indicate that this content does indeed have AD and/or BSL versions.

When a user opens the content in the video player after navigating from the Audio Described or Signed categories then the player will have the Audio Described or Signed button toggled on by default

It's worth noting, the term 'signed' to refer to signed content is common across different VOD services but from feedback from first-language BSL (British Sign Language) users the term BSL was more useful to them. After user testing with BSL in the category menu, a number of Hub users weren't familiar with what BSL meant so the decision was made to go with 'Signed - BSL'. This is understood by all and it also communicates to first-language BSL Hub users that the signed content is BSL rather than a simplified sign language like Makaton.


Tools and techniques

User interviews, competitor research, designs and prototypes in Figma and Framer and task-based usability testing (Userzoom).


Case Study

Full case study unavailable until the final work has been released. I'm happy to elaborate if there are any specific questions that I can answer without disclosing sensitive information.


Squirrel

Redesigning the on-boarding and set-up of a FinTech startup.

  • Client: Firebox - Date: February 2018 - Service: UX Design .

Summary

Firebox are an alternative homeware and lifestyle shopping site. A number of the products they sell are personalised products in which you can upload images to be printed on products such as cushions, facemasks, suitcase covers etc. I completely redesigned the product personalisation process.


Problem

Drop-off rates during the product personalisation process were quite high, particularly on mobile. Through user testing the current process, a number of key pain-points were identified.


Solution

After identifying common pain-points and by iterating through designs, wireframes, prototypes and validating with more user testing, all of the pain points identified were systematically addressed and resolved.


Tools and techniques

Contextual enquiry, competitor analysis, personas, user flows, design studios, paper prototyping, wireframing in Sketch, interactive prototypes in Marvel and Framer, user testing, design specifications, CSS and HTML.

Read the full case study here

Squirrel

Redesigning the on-boarding and set-up of a FinTech startup.

  • Client: Squirrel - Date: June 2017 - Service: UX Design .

Summary

Squirrel is a bank account, controlled by an app, aimed at making managing your money easy. We completely redesigned the onboarding, sign-up and activation process for their app.


Problem

A number of users had downloaded the app which had a convoluted onboarding and setup process. Users were skipping through this onboarding and consequently, on first using the app, didn't really understand how to use it. The result of this was they never continued using Squirrel.


Solution

We took the 3 stage process of onboarding, sign-up and activation, merging all three in to one combined linear flow, cutting the number of steps, and vastly shortening the copy by augmenting it with icons and diagrams to reduce cognitive load of a previously text heavy experience. We were also able to gain the user's trust in using the app and the service by highlighting early on the types of protection their money had by using the familiar logos of the bank that was protecting their money, and the financial standards agency that authorised and regulated Squirrel.

Read the full case study here
